G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify provisions of a custody or parenting‑time order where “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” has occurred and the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify provisions of a custody or parenting‑time order where “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” has occurred and the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Plaintiff moves this Court pursuant to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28**, **c. 209C, § 20**, and the Court’s equitable powers under **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, to modify said Judgment on the grounds that a substantial and material change in circumstances has occurred affecting the welfare of the minor child, **Emily Johnson (age 8)**.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The court’s paramount consideration is always the child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal cases, the best interests of the child are the paramount concern, and it interprets the governing statute to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests. The court’s analysis of the ‘real advantage’ test is framed around how to determine those best interests, while also noting that the custodial parent’s interests are considered only because they are intertwined with the child’s welfare. This directly supports the proposition that the court’s paramount consideration is always the child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute…provides that…[a child] shall not…be removed out of this commonwealth…unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined…. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The court’s paramount consideration is always the child’s best interests.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in custody matters “the governing principle” and “dominating rule” is the welfare of the child and affirms the decree on that basis. The court cites and adopts prior cases emphasizing that the child’s welfare/happiness is the controlling consideration over parents’ wishes, confirming that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins… and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions have consistently found that significant relocation or a change in the practical feasibility of a parenting schedule may constitute a material change warranting modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation in the context of G.L. c. 208, § 30 and joint physical custody, but it does not frame relocation or change in feasibility of the parenting plan as a “material change” standard for modification. Instead, it treats relocation as a removal question governed by a best‑interests analysis under § 30, and when referencing the ALI Principles’ language about “substantial change in circumstances,” it does so descriptively, not as a Massachusetts rule that significant relocation is a material change warranting modification. Therefore, it does not clearly establish the proposition about Massachusetts appellate decisions consistently treating such relocation as a material-change basis for modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]….’ … ALI Principles… support the view that where ‘neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility,’ the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions have consistently found that significant relocation or a change in the practical feasibility of a parenting schedule may constitute a material change warranting modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: This decision is a removal/relocation case, but it is not about modification of a parenting schedule based on a post‑judgment material change; rather, it applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal test under G.L. c. 208, § 30. The opinion does not discuss ‘material change’ or modification standards in connection with significant relocation or feasibility of parenting time, nor does it survey Massachusetts appellate decisions on that issue. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that relocation or changes in the practicality of a schedule constitute a material change warranting modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas…”

*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions have consistently found that significant relocation or a change in the practical feasibility of a parenting schedule may constitute a material change warranting modification.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosen v. Rosen concerns equitable credits against child support arrears and the statutory bar on retroactive modification; it does not analyze when a “significant relocation” or a change in the feasibility of a parenting schedule constitutes a material change justifying modification. The only relocation-type facts are that the children changed residence from mother to father over time, but these are discussed in the context of equitable credit and termination dates, not as a doctrinal treatment of material-change standards for parenting plans. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, to receive an equitable credit against a child support arrearage, the support payor must demonstrate that (1) the support recipient agreed (a) to transfer custody of the child to the payor for an extended period of time not contemplated in the original custody order, and (b) to accept the payor’s direct support of the child as an alternative method of satisfying the payor’s child support obligation… Where these factors are present, a judge may find ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warranting an equitable credit.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: The child’s welfare and the avoidance of undue travel burden are vital considerations in parenting‑time orders.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly establishes that the child’s welfare and best interests are the paramount concern in custody and visitation decisions, and in the removal context it requires consideration of the impact of a move on the child, including the feasibility of alternative visitation schedules. While it does not explicitly discuss ‘travel burden’ in terms of mileage or inconvenience, its removal analysis requires weighing the effect of relocation on the noncustodial parent’s contact and the child’s stability, which necessarily encompasses concern about the burdens associated with travel for parenting time.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30… The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child… In the second stage, the question is whether on balance, taking into consideration the interests of the custodial and noncustodial parents, and the impact of such a move on the child, removal is in the best interests of the child… [factors include] the possibility of an alternative visitation schedule for the noncustodial parent.”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.proposition: The child’s welfare and the avoidance of undue travel burden are vital considerations in parenting‑time orders.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses what should be considered in removal/visitation (parenting‑time) decisions and emphasizes that the child’s best interests require more than just facilitating frequent contact with the noncustodial parent. It holds that courts must consider the impact of travel/visitation arrangements and possible alternative visitation schedules, together with the overall welfare of the child and custodial parent, rather than treating the difficulty of visitation from a move as dispositive. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s welfare and avoidance of undue travel burden are vital considerations in parenting‑time orders.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents, … and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent…. He did not discuss the possibility of alternate visiting schedules which would preserve and foster the important relationship of the children with their father.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A court may properly modify midweek visitation where the parent’s relocation imposes excessive travel on a school‑age child.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation and custody/removal standards, not a discrete modification of midweek visitation due to excessive travel for a school‑age child. The court in fact finds that weekly travel between Northborough and Providence (about one hour each way) can be accomplished "with ease" and is "not unreasonable" under the existing schedule, and it ultimately authorizes relocation with appropriate visitation. Nothing in the holding endorses modifying midweek visitation because travel is excessive; if anything, it minimizes the burden of such travel on the child in these circumstances.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Transporting Caleb on a weekly basis pursuant to the current visitation schedule was found by the judge to be accomplished ‘with ease,’ and with little burden on the mother.... Finding no. 55: ‘The Court finds that the Mother can continue to drive to Massachusetts to pick up the minor child for her parenting time with relative ease... The travel time of one hour each way is not unreasonable under the current custody schedule.’"

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Where the existing order impairs a child’s academic functioning or emotional health, modification is warranted.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is not a modification case and does not discuss standards for modifying an existing custody order based on impairment of a child’s academic functioning or emotional health. Instead, it addresses the initial custody determination under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and how G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) interacts with that standard, with a focus on stability and primary caregiver issues. It does not hold or suggest that a showing of impaired academic or emotional functioning warrants modification of an existing order, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.proposition: Where the existing order impairs a child’s academic functioning or emotional health, modification is warranted.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the appropriate procedural vehicle for changing a custody order (requiring a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28), not with the substantive standard for when a modification is warranted. Although the court notes the children’s special emotional and educational needs and the mother’s problematic parenting, it does not articulate or apply a rule that an existing order which impairs a child’s academic functioning or emotional health must be modified. The cited language concerns process, not the substantive modification standard claimed in the proposition.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

*Miller v. Miller*, 478 Mass. 642 (2018).proposition: The Court’s duty is to promote stability and continuity for the minor child.

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Court’s duty is to promote stability and continuity for the minor child.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that in custody and adoption decisions the trial judge’s task is to determine and protect the child’s best interests, including weighing the value of the child’s current stable environment and continuity of relationships against other prospective benefits. The court expressly recognizes the importance of stability in a young child’s life and discusses the need to consider whether the current or proposed placement will provide a stable, consistent environment, which aligns with a duty to promote stability and continuity for the minor child.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).proposition: The Court’s duty is to promote stability and continuity for the minor child.
*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that termination decisions must be made based on the child’s best interests, and that courts must consider the impact of prolonged parental unfitness because “childhood is fleeting.” While the case does not use the exact words “stability and continuity,” its focus on timely permanency, the harm of forced separation from a stable caretaker, and deference to adoptive parents for ongoing visitation reflects a duty to promote a stable, continuous placement for the child. Thus it supports the general principle that the court’s role is to advance stability and continuity for the minor child.
*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).relevant_excerpt: “Because childhood is fleeting, a parent’s unfitness is not temporary if it is reasonably likely to continue for a prolonged or indeterminate period. … ‘At some point the court must say, ‘Enough,’ … and act in the children’s best interests.’ … One of [the statutory factors] is that, as a result of the mother’s inability to provide for her child’s needs, ‘the child has formed a strong, positive bond with [her] substitute caretaker,’ and the forced separation of the child from that caretaker would cause a harm which the mother was ill equipped to handle.”
